definitions.definition: Able to be brought to a form where all occurrences of the dependent and the independent variable are on opposite sides of the equal sign.

definitions.label_groups: mathematical analysis , of a topological space

definitions.definition: Any of several technical senses relating to the behavior of polynomials or objects over which polynomials can be defined :

subdefinitions.definition: Having no repeated roots (where roots are considered in an algebraic closure ) ( Galois theory , obsolete , of a polynomial P {\displaystyle P} ) Such that none of the irreducible factors of P {\displaystyle P} have a repeated root.
examples: x 2 + 1 {\displaystyle x^{2}+1} is separable , since its roots are i {\displaystyle i} and âˆ’ i {\displaystyle -i} .

subdefinitions.definition: Such that the minimal polynomial of every element of E {\displaystyle E} is a separable polynomial.
labels: of an algebraic field extension E
subdefinitions.label_groups: Galois theory , of an algebraic field extension E / F {\displaystyle E/F}

subdefinitions.definition: Satisfying any of several technical conditions on the center of the algebra which generalize the situation of field extensions; see Separable algebra on  Wikipedia. Wikipedia
labels: of an algebra over a ring
subdefinitions.label_groups: abstract algebra , of an algebra over a ring

secondary_definitions: ( mathematics , of a differential equation ) Able to be brought to a form where all occurrences of the dependent and the independent variable are on opposite sides of the equal sign.
( mathematical analysis , of a topological space ) Having a countable dense subset .
( mathematics , algebra ) Any of several technical senses relating to the behavior of polynomials or objects over which polynomials can be defined :
